content:
The Act may be cited as the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 defines key terms related to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features, including Blunt Reservoir feature, Commission, nonpreferential lease parcel, Pierre Canal feature, and preferential leaseholder. The Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006 defines terms related to the Oahe Unit, James Division, including preferential leaseholder, preferential lease parcel, Secretary, and State. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain features with associated liabilities. The State of South Dakota may accept ownership of certain features with associated liabilities, including outstanding obligations related to expired easements and rights granted in, on, over, or across the features. The Commission will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option extended to preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations shall bind the State, and conveyances will be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights. A preferential leaseholder shall be subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights and outstanding permits or licenses on the leased parcel. Conveyances to the State will be subject to reservations and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948 for wildlife conservation purposes. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the leased parcel from the Secretary or the Commission acting on behalf of the Secretary. A preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The purchase can be made on specific terms, including a cash purchase option. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission at a value determined under paragraph (4), minus ten percent of that value. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. For parcels under $10,000, cash purchase is required. The option to purchase must be exercised within 5 years. Until then, the lease can continue under the same terms. The parcel's value is based on fair market value for agricultural purposes. The value of a preferential lease parcel is determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent. Any disputes over the value are resolved according to federal regulations. If the leaseholder fails to purchase the parcel within the specified time, it will be offered to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The Secretary shall offer to convey a parcel to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited as miscellaneous funds for county taxes on lands received by the State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Additionally, the Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Land exchanges may be allowed for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. The person can exchange land elsewhere in the State for a nonpreferential lease parcel or unleased parcel at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. Priority is given to current lessees and adjoining landowners for exchanges. A perpetual easement is reserved for water conveyance structures. The United States will not be liable for damages related to any act, omission, or occurrence after the conveyance of a parcel, except for acts of negligence. This does not add to any liability under the Federal Tort Claims Act. The Secretary will continue to lease preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels until they are conveyed. During the interim period, the Secretary will lease preferential and nonpreferential lease parcels under existing terms. Within 180 days of enactment, parcel descriptions will be provided to the State. Archeological collections will be transferred to the South Dakota State Historical Society. $750,000 is authorized for implementation. Authorization of $750,000 for implementation of the Act, including reimbursement for expenses incurred by the Secretary, Commission, and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks.
